title: University Ranking Africa
text: provided code snippet showcases use universityrankingafrica package R prepare visual map highlighting countries highest-ranked universities Africa. primary aim utilize dataset’s “Rank Africa” column, contains university rankings, extract display distribution top-ranked universities across African countries. goal explore various aggregation methods rank countries based universities’ rankings.

title: University Ranking Africa
text: first try select highest ranked university country use rank countries.
code: library(universityrankingafrica) library(tidyverse) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth)   top_ranked_per_country <- universityrankingafrica |>    select(University, Country, `Rank Africa`) |>    group_by(Country) |>    filter(`Rank Africa` == min(`Rank Africa`)) |>    ungroup()  world <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")  africa_map_1 <- left_join(world,                          top_ranked_per_country, by = c("name" = "Country")) |>     filter(continent == "Africa")  plot <- ggplot() +   theme_void() +   geom_sf(data = africa_map, aes(fill = `Rank Africa`), color = "white", lwd = 0) +   scale_fill_gradientn(name = "Rank Africa",                         trans = "log",                        labels = scales::label_number(accuracy = 1),                        colors = c("#2E8B57","#9DBF9E", "#FCB97D", "#A84268"),                        na.value = "grey80") +   labs(title = "Top-Ranked Universities in Africa", ) +   theme(legend.position = c(0, 0.4), legend.direction = "horizontal",         plot.title = element_text(size = 20, hjust = 3, vjust = 0))  plot ggsave("plot/africa_map_1.png", plot, width = 10, height = 8, dpi = 300)

title: University Ranking Africa
text: approach, aim expand scope considering top two universities country. process involves selecting two highest-ranked universities within every country calculating median rankings. way, obtain broader perspective educational excellence within nation. method allows comprehensive evaluation compared Method 1, providing nuanced understanding educational landscape across Africa.
code: library(universityrankingafrica) library(tidyverse) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth)  #we only modify the way we're ranking the countries top_2_ranked_per_country <- universityrankingafrica |>    select(University, Country, `Rank Africa`) |>    group_by(Country) |>    slice_head(n = 2) |>    ungroup() |>    group_by(Country) |>    summarize(Avg_Rank = median(`Rank Africa`)) |>    ungroup()  world <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")  africa_map_2 <- left_join(world,                          top_2_ranked_per_country, by = c("name" = "Country")) |>     filter(continent == "Africa")  plot <- ggplot() +   theme_void() +   geom_sf(data = africa_map_2, aes(fill = `Avg_Rank`), color = "white", lwd = 0) +   scale_fill_gradientn(name = "Rank Africa",                         trans = "log",                        labels = scales::label_number(accuracy = 1),                        colors = c("#2E8B57","#9DBF9E", "#FCB97D", "#A84268"),                        na.value = "grey80") +   labs(title = "Top-Ranked Universities in Africa", ) +   theme(legend.position = c(0, 0.4), legend.direction = "horizontal",         plot.title = element_text(size = 20, hjust = 3, vjust = 0))   plot ggsave("plot/africa_map_2.png", plot, width = 10, height = 8, dpi = 300)

title: University Ranking Africa
text: Method 3 takes inclusive stance considering universities within country. Instead focusing solely top-performing institutions, approach involves aggregating rankings universities country computing median. method offers holistic view educational standards within country. provides comprehensive ranking considers collective performance universities, may offer insights differing selective approaches Method 1 Method 2.
code: library(universityrankingafrica) library(tidyverse) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth)  #we only modify the way we're ranking the countries all_ranked_per_country <- universityrankingafrica |>    select(University, Country, `Rank Africa`) |>    group_by(Country) |>    summarize(Avg_Rank = median(`Rank Africa`), .groups = "drop")  world <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")  africa_map_3 <- left_join(world,                          all_ranked_per_country, by = c("name" = "Country")) |>     filter(continent == "Africa")  plot <- ggplot() +   theme_void() +   geom_sf(data = africa_map_3, aes(fill = `Avg_Rank`), color = "white", lwd = 0) +   scale_fill_gradientn(name = "Rank Africa",                         trans = "log",                        labels = scales::label_number(accuracy = 1),                        colors = c("#2E8B57","#9DBF9E", "#FCB97D", "#A84268"),                        na.value = "grey80") +   labs(title = "Top-Ranked Universities in Africa", ) +   theme(legend.position = c(0, 0.4), legend.direction = "horizontal",         plot.title = element_text(size = 20, hjust = 3, vjust = 0),         plot.margin = margin(0, 0, 0, 0, unit = "cm") )  plot ggsave("plot/africa_map_3.png", plot, width = 10, height = 8, dpi = 300)

title: University Ranking Africa
text: Method 1 - Top-Ranked Universities per Country: Focuses single highest-ranked university country, offering clear snapshot top performers potentially overlooking broader educational landscape. Method 2 - Top Two Universities per Country: Considers top two universities, providing slightly broader perspective maintaining selectivity. Offers nuanced view without overwhelming details. Method 3 - Universities per Country: Takes inclusive approach considering universities, offering comprehensive potentially diluted view educational standards. method merits: Method 1 offers clarity, Method 2 balances selectivity breadth, Method 3 provides inclusivity may sacrifice precision. Choosing appropriate method depends specific objectives desired depth understanding evaluating educational excellence across African countries.
